newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Ex-Soviet states discuss Afghan situation - Tass.
newsitem.headline: Ex-Soviet states discuss Afghan situation - Tass.

text.p: Security officials from Russia and eight other former Soviet republics convened an urgent meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss strategy following gains by the Taleban militia in Afghanistan, Itar-Tass news agency said.
Officials were not immediately able to confirm the report.

The sudden collapse of opposition to the Islamists, allowing the Taleban to sweep close to the old Soviet frontier, sparked alarm in Moscow at the spread of fundamentalist Islam and fears that a wave of refugees and defeated fighters could destabilise countries like Tajikistan in formerly Soviet Central Asia.
Quoting the secretary-general of the nine-member Collective Security Council, Vladimir Zemsky, Tass said the meeting would put forward suggestions for further action.

Four of the five former Soviet states in Central Asia -- Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan -- are signatories with Russia of the Treaty on Collective Security, which came into force in 1994. Turkmenistan is not a member of the council. Belarus and the Caucasus states of Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia are the remaining signatories.
The treaty, which operates under the aegis of the 12-member Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), allows for mutual military assistance in the event of external aggression.
Russia already has some 20,000 troops and frontier guards deployed in Tajikistan, where a fragile peace is holding after four years of civil war.
Those forces and the troops of some Central Asian states near the mountainous Afghan frontier have been placed on alert following the rapid Taleban advance at the weekend.
